sections.title: Title

rules.description: Use Markdown H1 headings.
Aim for 50 to 60 characters; 80 characters maximum.
Use cue words such as `Guide to`, `About`, `Understand`, `FAQ`, or `Introduction to`. Do not use active verbs like `Learn` or `How to`
Capitalize only the first word and any proper nouns (sentence-style capitalization).
For verbs, use the base form over the gerund form. For example, use `Understand` instead of `Understanding`..
Use the `FAQ:` prefix for question compilations. Don't name FAQ articles as tasks.
Avoid one- or two-word titles and empty verbs like *make*, *manage*, or *put*.
Don't use punctuation marks, such as colons, semicolons, or dashes except the `FAQ:` prefix.

examples:
| Usage   | Example                                |
	|:--------|:---------------------------------------|
	| **Use** | Guide to RLN rate limiting             |
	| Avoid   | Limiting RLN rate                      |
	| **Use** | Understand Codex API limits            |
	| Avoid   | Understanding Codex API limits         |
	| **Use** | FAQ: Codex billing and usage           |
	| Avoid   | Questions on Codex billing and usage   |

sections.title: Subtitle

rules.description: Use a Markdown H4 for the subtitle placed right under the H1 title.
One sentence only; no links, lists, or inline formatting.
Do not end with a period.
Stay under 20 words.
Use an base-form verb that states the purpose or benefit
Add new value beyond the title; don’t repeat or rephrase the H1.

examples:
- **Title**: *About Logos Connect communication protocol* / **Subtitle**: *Understand Waku’s peer-to-peer protocol for private, censorship-resistant messaging*
- **Title**: *Guide to Logos Storage API* / **Subtitle**: *Learn how Codex provides real-time blockchain data through a single API*

sections.title: Access callout (optional)

rules.description: Place it after the title and subtitle, before the introduction.
Use the `Note` callout style.
Use label-led, scannable content (no explanations).
Include permissions (software role or permission level).
Include product (product version or edition), if applicable.
If multiple permissions/products apply, use commas.
Do not include knowledge, skills, or required tools.
Omit the callout entirely if no permission/product constraints exist.

examples:
> **Note**
  >
  > - **Permissions**: Node operators, Site operators
  > - **Product**: Logos Storage v1.4.0 or later

sections.title: Callouts

rules.description: Use callouts sparingly and avoid placing them consecutively.
One callout maximum per section
Keep each callout concise (≤ 2 short sentences). If the content needs a list or multiple paragraphs, move it into the body under a heading.
Ensure the callout content is directly relevant to the nearby text.
Use the appropriate type: `Tip`, `Note`, `Important`, or `Caution`.
For the allowed callout types and when to use them, see the [writing rules](../../3-validating-design/writing-rules/README.md).

examples:
> **Note:**
>
> Keep container resources within the documented limits to avoid throttling.

rules.description: Include the intro components in this order: Overview, Diagram (optional), Use case example (optional), Comparison (optional).
Write a 50–100 word paragraph explaining the concept, its purpose, and its relevance.
Provide context or background information to help readers understand the concept.
Explain the concept's main points using one paragraph per idea.
Link only when it helps disambiguate or deep-dive (aim ≤3 links).
If the overview is long or complex, link to other supportive documents.
Use one diagram or image per idea.
To show an architecture, flow, or process, use a Mermaid diagram.
For UI or CLI outputs, when the interface itself is the concept, use a screenshot or image.
For simple relationships, use a Mermaid diagram. Even two boxes and an arrow is clearer than prose.

sections.title: Use case example (optional)

rules.description: Provide a concrete, real-world scenario for the product feature.
Use a bullet list format to present multiple use cases clearly.

examples:
> ⚙️ **Example:**
>
> *For example, you can configure custom environment variables so they are set every time you open a codespace, and you can ensure that temporary files are retained when the codespace stops.*

sections.title: Comparison (optional)

rules.description: Use a paragraph or list for simple comparisons with ≤2 options.
Use a table for complex comparisons with 3 or more options.
Focus on key decision factors, such as performance, complexity, cost, prerequisites, and limitations.
Use direct language in short sentences so different options are easy to scan.
Highlight trade‑offs clearly.
examples: Option A is faster but less secure

rules.description: Provide real-world guidance.
examples: Choose A if you need X
choose B if you care about Y".

> ⚙️ **Example:**
>
> | Feature             | Relay                                       | RLN Relay                                   |
> |:--------------------|:--------------------------------------------|:--------------------------------------------|
> | Spam protection     | None – all peers can flood messages         | Enforces per-peer rate limits, economic penalties |
> | Privacy impact      | Neutral – standard Pub/Sub propagation      | Neutral – preserves Relay’s anonymity properties |
> | Resource guarantees | Relies on network-level quotas, no enforcement | Stronger resilience due to rate limiting |

sections.title: "The basics"

rules.description: Use a Markdown H2 with the exact text "The basics".
Place this section after the introduction and before the next H2 section.
Include exactly one unordered list with three items (no code blocks or callouts here).
Write one complete sentence per bullet (two short sentences max), and end sentences with a period.
Use parallel wording in each bullet (same grammatical shape), focused on main ideas.
Order items from most important to least important.
Allow only same-page heading links; no external links.

examples:
> ⚙️ **Example:**
>
>- *Codespaces are fully managed, cloud-based development environments you can spin up in seconds.*
>- *They run in containers that match your repository’s configuration, so every contributor gets the same setup.*  
>- *You connect from your browser, VS Code, or the JetBrains Gateway. No local installation required.*
